hints_html:
This is a volume of revolution question. We can easily compute this since we are rotating about the x-axis.

The formula is given by

\(\displaystyle V = \pi \int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x^2}\,dx\)
hints_latex:
This is a volume of revolution question. We can easily compute this
since we are rotating about the \emph{x}-axis.

The formula is given by

$\displaystyle V = \pi \int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x^2}\,dx$
hints_raw:
This is a volume of revolution question. We can easily compute this since we are rotating about the ''x''-axis.
The formula is given by

<math> \displaystyle V = \pi \int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x^2}\,dx</math>
question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
Using the formula in the hint, we have

\[\begin{aligned} V &= \pi \int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x^2}\,dx \\ &= \lim_{b \to \infty} \pi \int_{1}^{b}\frac{1}{x^2}\,dx \\ &= \lim_{b \to \infty} \pi (-x^{-1}) \big|_{1}^{b} \\ &= \lim_{b \to \infty} \pi (-b^{-1} -(-(1)^{-1}))\\ &= \pi\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
Using the formula in the hint, we have

\begin{align*}
V &= \pi \int_{1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{x^2}\,dx \\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \pi \int_{1}^{b}\frac{1}{x^2}\,dx \\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \pi (-x^{-1}) \big|_{1}^{b} \\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \pi (-b^{-1} -(-(1)^{-1}))\\
&= \pi
\end{align*}

statement_html:
Torricelli’s Trumpet

Find the volume of the solid obtained from revolving \(\displaystyle y = 1/x\) about the x-axis where x has domain \(\displaystyle [1,\infty)\).
statement_latex:
\textbf{Torricelli's Trumpet}

Find the volume of the solid obtained from revolving
$\displaystyle y = 1/x$ about the \emph{x}-axis where \emph{x} has
domain $\displaystyle [1,\infty)$.
statement_raw:
'''Torricelli's Trumpet''' 

Find the volume of the solid obtained from revolving <math> \displaystyle y = 1/x</math> about the ''x''-axis where ''x'' has domain <math> \displaystyle [1,\infty)</math>.
